item.title: Is morality based on duty?
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

I won’t bother typing up a big slap of text (that’s your job), but I think it’s the other way around.

Morality defines what is right and what is wrong. Right or wrong is different for each person. If a duty doesn’t fit with your morality, you will hesitate to perform that duty, or you simply won’t do it. If you think defending your country is morally right, you will do everything your commander tells you to do.

item.title: Is morality based on duty?
item.dc:creator: @Original_Daniel Original Daniel
item.description:
@Original_Daniel wrote:

I know but a bit part of it could be “It’s not based on duty because it is based on x because y”

When someone recognizes a duty, that person commits himself/herself to the cause involved without considering the self-interested courses of actions that may have been relevant previously. This is not to suggest that living a life of duty precludes one from the best sort of life, but duty does involve some sacrifice of immediate self-interest.

How can duty be based on morals when you don’t sacrifice something, and it is in your own interests to help others?

Every action is in our own interest - even if someone donates lots of money towards research for a sickness they don’t have, they wouldn’t do it if they didn’t feel good about it.
